name: Type A — Pure Methodology Letter (fictional applicant and recommender)
description: Methodology recommender who used the petitioner's code in their own research. Tests 'original developer extends own model' pattern.

input.proposed_endeavor: Dr. Sarah Kim's proposed endeavor is to advance precision medicine by developing novel longitudinal statistical models that profile individual patient trajectories and identify heterogeneous subgroups.
input.target_pillar: Methodological Innovation in Longitudinal Statistical Modeling
input.recommender_title: Full Professor of Epidemiology and Biostatistics; Director, Biostatistics Center
input.recommender_background: PhD in Psychometrics, Midwest State University. Research on structural equation modeling, latent agreement, and health literacy.
input.recommender_credentials: Multiple NSF and NIH-funded grants. Published extensively on longitudinal clustering methods. Developed a growth mixture model (published in a top rheumatology journal, [X] citations in [Y] years).
input.recommender_independence: Never collaborated. Found work through literature and requested her code.
input.how_they_discovered: Read her paper in a top quantitative psychology journal and requested her statistical code to use in his own NIH-funded cancer diagnosis project.

contributions.before: Dr. Bauer's own growth mixture model required the transition point (knot) to be pre-specified using domain knowledge, and did not allow for individually different measurement times.
contributions.what_petitioner_did: Developed a bilinear spline growth model with time-invariant covariates (BLSGM-TICs) that estimates an individual knot for each subject and works within a framework of individual measurement occasions.
contributions.enables_now: Researchers can explore knot differences across individuals without pre-specification; handles real-world data with varying measurement times.
contributions.validation: Dr. Bauer requested her code and applied it to his NIH-funded cancer diagnosis pilot study.

contributions.before: Mixture-of-experts (MoEs) models had never been applied to longitudinal data.
contributions.what_petitioner_did: Extended her BLSGM to create a longitudinal MoEs model, then a parallel BLSGM (PBLSGM) and parallel mixture model (PBLSGMM).
contributions.enables_now: Researchers can cluster individuals based on multiple concurrent longitudinal outcomes simultaneously.
contributions.validation: All three models accepted in the most prestigious journal in applied statistics in the field.

contributions.before: Dr. Bauer's latent kappa concept (published [X] years prior) lacked validated cutpoints for acceptable cluster agreement.
contributions.what_petitioner_did: Validated latent kappa as a robust metric via simulation studies and established a new cutpoint of 0.8.
contributions.enables_now: Broadened practical application of Dr. Bauer's own statistical concept.
contributions.validation: Updated Dr. Bauer's original theory — confirmed by Dr. Bauer himself.

input.federal_national_hook: NIH-funded research; AI transformation of healthcare; cancer diagnosis and prevention.
input.closing_strength: irreplaceable figure in our shared field

assertions: Letter written entirely in first person from Dr. Bauer's perspective
Independence stated explicitly in paragraph 1
Specific discovery story described (read paper, requested code)
BLSGM-TICs acronym used and explained
Journal named as the most prestigious in the field
'As the original developer of the model' framing used
NIH cancer project mentioned as concrete validation
Latent kappa improvement described
Closing includes 'irreplaceable figure' or equivalent
No third-person references to Dr. Bauer
Draft flags appended for any unverified statistics
expected_output: Complete Type A letter (800-1500 words) in first person from Dr. Bauer's perspective, with before/after framing on all three contributions, BLSGM-TICs named and explained, NIH cancer project validation, independence stated in paragraph 1, draft flags appended.

name: Type B — Domain Application Letter (fictional clinical recommender)
description: Clinical practitioner who encountered the work at a seminar. Tests application-focused letter with specific patient populations and numbers.

input.proposed_endeavor: Dr. Sarah Kim's proposed endeavor is to advance precision medicine by developing machine learning models to profile individual patient trajectories and guide clinical decision-making.
input.target_pillar: Clinical Application — Precision Medicine and Patient Outcome Prediction
input.recommender_title: Executive Medical Director of Clinical Development
input.recommender_background: M.D. from a leading medical school, Ph.D. from a leading research university. 35+ years in clinical and regulatory research. Experience at major academic medical centers and pharmaceutical companies.
input.recommender_credentials: Extensive experience in drug development from bench to bedside. Led clinical trials across oncology, pulmonology, and rheumatology.
input.recommender_independence: Different departments at the same company (400+ scientists); never worked or collaborated with Dr. Kim directly.
input.how_they_discovered: Met at an internal scientific seminar where Dr. Kim presented ML results identifying patients likely to experience adverse events in the placebo group.

contributions.problem: Evaluating time-varying treatment effects in chronic diseases — treatment effects differ across time points and recovery rates vary by phase.
contributions.application: Dr. Kim's linear-linear model treated recovery as a nonlinear trajectory with two phases, enabling evaluation across the full treatment duration.
contributions.outcome: Applied to evaluate a biologic treatment for rheumatoid arthritis — established a comprehensive intervention procedure with high efficacy.
contributions.numbers: Rheumatoid arthritis affects approximately 1.3 million Americans.

contributions.problem: Identifying non-responders to surgery before it is performed — existing models misclassified patients based on baseline characteristics alone.
contributions.application: Dr. Kim's stepwise model identified non-responders based on recovery process patterns, incorporating genomics, clinical, demographic, and insurance data.
contributions.outcome: Applied to a high-volume surgical procedure — physicians identified likely non-responders and recommended alternative therapy, reducing unnecessary procedures.
contributions.numbers: [N] such procedures conducted annually in the US; approximately [X]% are non-responders.

contributions.problem: No systematic approach to evaluate treatment effects based on multiple concurrent clinical factors simultaneously.
contributions.application: Dr. Kim's joint development model evaluated the correlation between recovery processes of two clinical factors for each patient.
contributions.outcome: Shortened clinical trial duration; patients in placebo group received treatment sooner; fewer required site visits during long-term recovery.
contributions.numbers: Applied to a chronic respiratory disease affecting approximately [N] Americans.

input.federal_national_hook: Precision Medicine Initiative; FDA drug approval process; NIH clinical trials infrastructure.

assertions: Letter written entirely in first person from Dr. Ingram's perspective
Medical credentials established prominently
Independence (different departments at large company) stated in paragraph 1
Seminar discovery story specific and vivid
Precision Medicine Initiative named as national context
Each application has a named condition or procedure
At least one concrete patient population statistic
Closing includes 'strongest recommendation and full support'
Accessible to a USCIS officer — not overly technical
expected_output: Complete Type B letter (800-1500 words) in first person from Dr. Ingram's perspective, with seminar discovery story, Precision Medicine Initiative national hook, three named clinical applications with patient population statistics, closing with 'strongest recommendation and full support'.

name: Type C — Hybrid Letter (methodology + education application, fictional recommender)
description: Academic methodologist validating both technical innovation and domain application in education.

input.proposed_endeavor: Dr. Sarah Kim's proposed endeavor is to advance precision education in the United States by developing longitudinal statistical models that profile children's academic growth and guide individualized curriculum design.
input.target_pillar: Precision Education — Profiling Children's Academic Development
input.recommender_title: Associate Professor, Department of Psychology and Human Development
input.recommender_background: PhD in Quantitative Psychology. Former faculty at two major research universities. Research: quantitative methods for social sciences.
input.recommender_credentials: PI/Co-PI for $[X] million in research grants. Published [N] peer-reviewed articles. Research focus: quantitative methods in education and psychology.
input.recommender_independence: Never collaborated. Began following her work after reading her paper in the most prestigious journal in quantitative psychology.
input.how_they_discovered: Read her paper on extending mixture-of-experts models to investigate heterogeneity of trajectories.

contributions.before: Existing reparameterization models in quantitative psychology produced coefficients not directly related to developmental theory — educators could not interpret or apply findings.
contributions.what_petitioner_did: Introduced a transformation function and matrix that directly related model coefficients to developmental theory.
contributions.enables_now: Teachers can quantitatively assess how teaching strategies affect learning — enabling precision education practice.
contributions.validation: Published in a top quantitative methods journal.

contributions.before: No model could simultaneously account for a large number of covariates in explaining individual differences in academic trajectories.
contributions.what_petitioner_did: Developed a mixture-of-experts model evaluating relative importance of 100+ covariates, dividing students into subgroups.
contributions.enables_now: Researchers identify which factors have direct vs. indirect effects on academic performance. Policy makers and educators design targeted interventions.
contributions.validation: Published in the most prestigious journal in quantitative psychology.

contributions.problem: Educators designed curricula without understanding how reading and math abilities develop concurrently and intercorrelate.
contributions.application: Dr. Kim's joint development model showed that reading and mathematics intercorrelate significantly in early grades.
contributions.outcome: Designed intervention programs that improve math by enhancing reading skills; curriculum differentiated across student subgroups from kindergarten through Grade 5.
contributions.numbers: U.S. students' reading and mathematics proficiency rates (NAEP national assessment data).

input.federal_national_hook: U.S. K-12 education competitiveness; NAEP proficiency data; precision education as national policy priority.

assertions: Letter establishes university credentials prominently
Grant PI track record mentioned
Independence stated clearly in paragraph 1
Specific paper discovery mentioned
Most prestigious journal in quantitative psychology named
Transformation function and matrix explained in plain language
Mixture-of-experts model with 100+ covariates detail included
Reading-math intercorrelation and early-grade threshold mentioned
National competitiveness framing present
Both methodology and application sections clearly present (Type C)
expected_output: Complete Type C letter (800-1500 words) in first person from Dr. Torres's perspective, with both methodology section (transformation function, mixture-of-experts model) and application section (reading-math intercorrelation), grant credentials established, national K-12 competitiveness framing.
